Award.AwardTitle: Probability Density Function of Dislocation Free Path Length: Experimental Determination through GND Measurements
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The dislocation mean free path length is a unifying concept in understanding plastic deformation across all pertinent length scales. Plasticity formulations that account directly for the motion of dislocations are stochastic processes because of the non-deterministic behavior of dislocations combined with the otherwise deterministic equations of solid mechanics. The mean free path length (MFPL) succeeds only partially in quantifying the dislocation free path length. It is also necessary to quantify the probability density function (PDF) of the dislocation free path length. The overall research objective of this proposal is to measure experimentally the MFPL and the PDF of dislocation free path length and relate them experimentally to the deformation quantity of plastic shear strain in individual crystallographic slip systems. The concept of making such measurements has existed for several decades, but the capabilities to perform such experiments have not existed until now. This program will develop and use the methods and procedures to make these experimental measurements. In that context, the overall educational objective of this proposal is to promulgate not only the results from the research objective, but also the underlying mechanics concepts as well as experimental methods and procedures necessary to perform research of this type to the larger research community.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The safety and reliability of the nation's infrastructure and transportation systems depend upon the ability of scientists and engineers to predict the behavior of materials, especially metals, used to build that infrastructure. Metals experience mechanical failure due to the presence of defects called dislocations that cause permanent deformation as they move throughout the interior of the metal. The goal of this project is to measure the average distance and the variation in distances that dislocations travel as metals are deformed permanently and to relate these quantities to the amount of deformation that occurred. These quantities are very important for the development and validation of theories that predict the failure of metals. New fundamental understanding of the motion of defects in metals has the potential to lead to better theories that predict the behavior of materials in the nation's infrastructure with greater fidelity. The main educational goal of this project is to introduce the novel concepts and methods necessary to make the measurements to engineers and scientists through technical articles as well as teaching seminars at scientific conferences. A Ph.D. student will be supported in this project, thus enhancing the nation's human resources.

Institution.Name: Columbia University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metals are used extensively throughout society in buildings, transportation systems, bridges, railroads, computers, cell phones and kitchen appliances, among many other applications. A metal’s strength, ductility and toughness are the main properties of interest for engineers when they design mechanical systems that use metals.

Metals are typically manufactured in standard shapes such as flat sheets or bars with various cross-sectional shapes. In applications such as airplanes, cell phone cases, cars, trains and many others, the metals must be bent and formed into the final shape. Plasticity is the property that allows metal to be bent into other shapes. Engineers and scientists have studied the plasticity of metals for over a hundred years, with both experiments and the development of theories. Remarkably, despite all these decades of effort, we are still not able to predict the plastic behavior of metals from fundamental theories. Therefore, we have to rely on experiments when designing materials. As a consequence, it can take up to 20 years to design and make a new metal alloy.

It is well understood that plastic deformation occurs due to the presence of defects called dislocations in the metal. As a metal is deformed plastically, the dislocations move through the material and also reproduce themselves. The average distance a dislocation moves through the metal is a fundamentally important parameter, called the dislocation Mean Free Path Length (MFPL). However, since dislocations are atomic-scale defects and also because metals are opaque, it has proven to be very difficult to measure the dislocation mean free path length.

 It is known that dislocations tend to agglomerate into “wall structures” when they finally come to a rest after moving. In this project, we developed a method to measure the distance between these wall structures, which allowed us to infer the dislocation mean free path length. Our results show that the dislocation mean free path length decreases as the “density” of dislocations in the wall structures increases. The mathematical relationship between the dislocation mean free path length and the wall dislocation density was found to hold across multiple length scales.  A more fundamental understanding of the dislocation mean free path length can lead to predictive models of the behavior of metals that can make infrastructure more robust, reliable and safe, as well as to dramatically reduce material development cycles.

 In addition, we developed methods to validate experimentally new theories that attempt to describe how metals can become harder as they are deformed. This validation method will help to develop ever better predictive models of the mechanical behavior of metals.


Last Modified: 03/23/2018
Modified by: Jeffrey W Kysar
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Metals are used extensively throughout society in buildings, transportation systems, bridges, railroads, computers, cell phones and kitchen appliances, among many other applications. A metal?s strength, ductility and toughness are the main properties of interest for engineers when they design mechanical systems that use metals. Metals are typically manufactured in standard shapes such as flat sheets or bars with various cross-sectional shapes. In applications such as airplanes, cell phone cases, cars, trains and many others, the metals must be bent and formed into the final shape. Plasticity is the property that allows metal to be bent into other shapes. Engineers and scientists have studied the plasticity of metals for over a hundred years, with both experiments and the development of theories. Remarkably, despite all these decades of effort, we are still not able to predict the plastic behavior of metals from fundamental theories. Therefore, we have to rely on experiments when designing materials. As a consequence, it can take up to 20 years to design and make a new metal alloy. It is well understood that plastic deformation occurs due to the presence of defects called dislocations in the metal. As a metal is deformed plastically, the dislocations move through the material and also reproduce themselves. The average distance a dislocation moves through the metal is a fundamentally important parameter, called the dislocation Mean Free Path Length (MFPL). However, since dislocations are atomic-scale defects and also because metals are opaque, it has proven to be very difficult to measure the dislocation mean free path length. It is known that dislocations tend to agglomerate into "wall structures" when they finally come to a rest after moving. In this project, we developed a method to measure the distance between these wall structures, which allowed us to infer the dislocation mean free path length. Our results show that the dislocation mean free path length decreases as the "density" of dislocations in the wall structures increases. The mathematical relationship between the dislocation mean free path length and the wall dislocation density was found to hold across multiple length scales. A more fundamental understanding of the dislocation mean free path length can lead to predictive models of the behavior of metals that can make infrastructure more robust, reliable and safe, as well as to dramatically reduce material development cycles. In addition, we developed methods to validate experimentally new theories that attempt to describe how metals can become harder as they are deformed. This validation method will help to develop ever better predictive models of the mechanical behavior of metals. Last Modified: 03/23/2018 Submitted by: Jeffrey W Kysar
